I'm beyond moved and proud of my pal Jimmy Kimmel for speaking so honestly about the birth of his son Billy, and speaking so personally and powerfully about the health problems the baby ran into - including now having a pre-existing condition for the rest of his life.  His opening monologue - from deep within - might very well become the springboard to redirecting this country's focus about health care. 
if you have 13 minutes ... the video clip in the link below is a must-see. we are one team, says Jimmy, the American team. 
"If your baby is going to die, and it doesn’t have to, it shouldn’t matter how much money you make. I think that’s something that, whether you’re a Republican or a Democrat or something else, we all agree on that, right?”

content:
the NYPD investigation into the death of NY Appeals Court Judge Sheila Abdus-Salaam has now been passed to the New York Medical Examiner. 
It's not closed - but the cops have not yet found any criminality to this death. Is it a suicide? it appears that way, although it's not a final judgement.  Stay tuned. 

The Judge's body - washing up on the banks of the Hudson River last month. She had been depressed - her mom committed suicide 5 years ago on Easter; her brother committed suicide 2 years later around the same time. 
Depressed, and few people ever knew it. 

Those who did know it, must be wracked with more than just sorrow. Those who didn't, are wracked perhaps in a different way.

This is Mental Health Awareness Month, and for all the Judge Sheila's who are out there - especially the young people, and the 22 veterans who kill themselves ever day - we owe it to them and to us to help bring mental health out of the closet, and begin to openly discuss it. Regularly.

The time for talk is not over - it's just beginning. 

In the name of Judge Sheila Abdus-Salaam. In the name of the brilliant author Jean Stein, who at the age of 83, committed suicide this past weekend on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. We're going to explore Mental Health in depth this Sunday at 11 a.m. on ABC7NY on Up Close

content:
HEALTH CARE DEBATE UPDATE! 

Here's a quick top-line review     by ABC News of the Congressional Budget Office "scores" before the latest round of amendments to the current Obamacare health care law. These are projected numbers... compared to current Obama care law.  The deficits will be reduced, but the number of insured will rise to 14 million next year, 24 million by 2026.  The AHCA is the plan to replace Obamacare..  will it be called "Trumpcare"??? 

*Deficits:  Reduce federal deficits by $337 billion over 10 years.

*Fewer Insured: 14 million fewer insured by 2018; 24 million fewer insured by 2026.

*Individual Market Premiums: 15-20% higher in 2018/2019. 10% lower by 2026.  

*WHO'S OPPOSED:  More than 50 industry and patient organizations have come out against the AHCA.  Among them --
 
AARP
American Cancer Society
American Hospital Association
America’s Hospitals and Health Systems
American Medical Association
American Heart Association
American Lung Association
March of Dimes
American Academy of Pediatrics
American Nurses Association
American Public Health Association
American Psychiatric Association
American Public Health Association
AFL-CIO
Catholic Health Association of the U.S.
National Education Association
Cystic Fibrosis Foundation
Consumers Union

*Leading conservative groups opposed to AHCA, include –
 
Heritage Foundation
Koch Brothers/Americans for Prosperity

*WHO'S IN FAVOR: More than 12 conservative public policy and political groups support the AHCA. Among them --
 
Club for Growth
Americans for Tax Reform
National Taxpayers Union
Citizens Against Government Waste
Log Cabin Republicans
Center for the American Experiment
Small Business and Entrepreneurship Council
National Right to Life Committee
Susan B. Anthony List

content:
U.S. Sen. Cory Booker  (D-NJ) responds to health care vote in congress. 

“No family should go bankrupt because a loved one has cancer. No senior should have to decide between buying their prescription drugs or paying for groceries. No woman should have to travel hundreds of miles to access essential reproductive health services.  
 
“This should never happen anywhere, and especially not in the richest country on the planet. What the GOP just passed in the House today flies in the face of these principles. It’s cruel, it’s wrong, and will cost lives.
 
“For the 24 million Americans who stand to lose coverage, the New Jerseyans who would pay thousands of dollars more each year for insurance, the families who would lose the guarantee that essential health services like birth control, prenatal care, and mental health care are covered, and for the people who could lose access to coverage just because they have a pre-existing condition, I will fight this morally and fiscally bankrupt bill in the Senate every step of the way.”
 
# # #

content:
i'm finding myself getting emotional as the week begins. mother's day on sunday, to be sure.. and missing my mom, Darlene Ritter.. who died at the way-young age of 61 in 1989. (She was about 17 when the picture below was taken.. a student at L.A. High School) 
But i'm also thinking about her because come Friday, the grandson she never met, Owen, will graduate college. We'll all be there, and both my mom and my dad will be in my heart. 
Neither of them graduated college - both going for a year, and then-  with their families not being able to afford it anymore- they dropped out.
Two years ago, my oldest daughter, Mia, graduated college. Last year, finally, I did - 44 years after I had been kicked out for anti-Vietnam war demonstrations. Now, Friday, Owen graduates. 
My parents would be so happy and proud. 
(the next graduation -- 2031, when my youngest daughter, my parents'  youngest grandchild, Ella, will graduate college. but i'll just focus on this week for now)

name: Bill Ritter

content: so the man leading the investigation into russian ties to The White House is fired by the man who lives in the White House.  President Donald J. Trump fires FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation director James Comey. the latest  on ABC7NY
name: Bill Ritter

content:
How President Donald J. Trump fired James Comey: 
A White House official confirms to ABC News that Oval Office Director of Operations Keith Schiller hand-delivered President Trump's termination letter to the FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters this afternoon, while Comey was out of town traveling. 
Comey's termination was read to him over the phone.

FBI agents and staff are said to be stunned by the news.   Inside the FBI there are discussions about whether Comey will be able to address the bureau he led one final time, but it is not clear that will happen.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Photos from Bill Ritter's post

content:
SENATORIAL REACTION TO COMEY FIRING: 
SEN. JOHN MCCAIN, R-AZ (statement)
“While the President has the legal authority to remove the Director of the FBI, I am disappointed in the President's decision to remove James Comey from office. James Comey is a man of honor and integrity, and he has led the FBI well in extraordinary circumstances. I have long called for a special congressional committee to investigate Russia's interference in the 2016 election. The president's decision to remove the FBI Director only confirms the need and the urgency of such a committee.”

SEN. BOB CORKER, R-TN (statement)
“While the case for removal of Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey laid out by Deputy Attorney General Rod J. Rosenstein was thorough, his removal at this particular time will raise questions,” said Corker. “It is essential that ongoing investigations are fulsome and free of political interference until their completion, and it is imperative that President Trump nominate a well-respected and qualified individual to lead the bureau at this critical time.”

SEN. MITCH MCCONNELL, R-KY, SENATE MAJORITY LEADER (statement)
“Once the Senate receives a nomination, we look forward to a full, fair, and timely confirmation process to fill the Director position. This is a critical role that is especially important as America faces serious threats at home and abroad.”

SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER, D-NY, SENATE MINORITY LEADER (tweet)
If we don't get a special prosecutor, every American will rightfully suspect that the decision to fire #Comey was part of a cover-up.

SEN. ROY BLUNT, R-MO (statement)
"Director Comey has served the country well in a number of different roles. Many, including myself, have questioned his actions more than once over the past year. I believe new leadership at he FBI will restore confidence in the organization and among the people who do the hard work to carry out its mission."

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS, I-VT (tweet)
Donald Trump’s decision to fire FBI Director James Comey raises serious questions about what his administration is hiding.

TOM PEREZ, CHAIR OF THE DEMOCRATIC NATIONAL COMMITTEE (statement)
“Donald Trump’s firing of James Comey is a brazen and disgraceful abuse of power.  The fact that the leadership of the Justice Department was complicit in manufacturing this joke of a rationale for Comey’s dismissal at the request of Trump is further evidence that nobody in this Administration can be trusted to lead an honest investigation into a serious national security issue.  It is time for leaders in both parties to come together and call for the appointment of a special prosecutor at the Department of Justice and an independent commission to conduct the kind of investigation that the American people deserve.”

SEN. TOM UDALL, D-NM (statement)
"This decision is chilling. It defies logic to believe that President Trump fired Director Comey -- who is investigating both Russia's interference in our election and the president's campaign for its ties to that attack on our democracy -- for any other reason than to interfere with the investigation. The Department of Justice must appoint a special counsel to continue the investigation. And it's more important than ever for an independent, bipartisan commission, modeled after the 9/11 commission, to get the full answers that Americans deserve about ties between Russia and President Trump’s team. FBI directors are appointed to 10-year terms to avoid political interference in the nation’s top law enforcement organization. It is high time that Republicans joined Democrats in exercising real oversight over the Trump Administration, and the confirmation process for the next FBI director would be a great place to start."

#BreakingNews     ILFRACOMBE, England (AP) -- A young British computer expert credited with cracking the WannaCry cyberattack has told The Associated Press he doesn't consider himself a hero but fights malware because "it's the right thing to do."
   In his first face-to-face interview, Marcus Hutchis said Monday hundreds of computer experts worked throughout the weekend to fight the virus, which which paralyzed computers in some 150 countries.
name: Bill Ritter

content:
The White House denies President Donald J. Trump disclosed highly classified information during his meeting last week with russian officials in the oval office.

but the The New York Times is reporting that the classified information he revealed to the russian foreign minister and the russian ambassador to the u.s. was "about an Islamic State {ISIS} plot," according to a former and current American official.  It was, says The Times, provided to the President, directly or indirectly, by a "foreign ally that closely guards its own secrets.... (and) was considered so sensitive that American officials did not share it widely within the United States government or pass it on to other allies."

Again, the Trump people claim it didn't happen.  but the allegations from two american officials - one current, one former - is sparking another firestorm of controversy around the Trump Administration. 

the russian meeting happened last week happened one day after the President fired the director of FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation, who was investigating Trump campaign ties to Russians, and Russia's attempt to influence the presidential election last fall.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Trump Revealed Highly Classified Intelligence to Russia, in Break With Ally, Officials Say

content:
Sources tell ABC News that former FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation director James Comey had a "common practice" of taking detailed and prolific notes of meetings. "He documents everything," one source said. 

And that's what is making news .. that Comey's "memo" details the following conversation with President Donald J. Trump on Feb. 14... in which he says Mr. Trump asked him to "let go" of the investigation into former National Security Adviser Mike Flynn and his ties to Russians. 

“I hope you can let this go,” the president allegedly told Mr. Comey, a source told ABC News.

 “I hope you can see your way clear to letting this go, to letting Flynn go,” Mr. Trump allegedly told Mr. Comey. “He is a good guy. I hope you can let this go.”

The source said that Comey only agreed that Flynn was a good guy and offered no other comment to the President.

content:
one year ago tonight... I spoke at the The New School for Social Research recognition ceremony for those graduating as part of the class of 2016.  44 years after I was  booted out of San Diego State University for protests against the war in Vietnam. 
Since then, I  have thought much about how to  help others return to college and finish what they started. I am committed to help figure out a way to do that... and help improve the surprising and surprisingly low number of college students who do not graduate. 
the graduation rate now averages about 52%.
that means that nearly half of the students who enroll in college don't graduate. 
We can do better. 
Below is my speech to my fellow grads - one year ago   today.

content:
It's always when you least expect it. Tragedy and carnage, violence and insanity. And on a hot spring day, with Times Square packed with people, there was no expectation that a young man would drive the wrong way on 7th Avenue from 42nd St. to 45th St., plowing into people along the way. 
in the end, an 18 year old woman was killed .. 22 people were hurt.. some of them seriously. 
A terrorist attack - that's the first thing that many people thought. And while at its basest this driver terrorized the busiest plot of land in New York, the NYPD says it doesn't appear this was anything but an act of lunacy. Was it drunken or drug induced - they don't yet know. 
But it was horrible. 
We're unraveling the story, with many reporters on the scene. and we'll have the latest on air and online at ABC7NY
name: Bill Ritter
title: 1 dead, 22 hurt after car plows into crowd in Times Square

content:
Her name is Barbara Murray - and talk about selfless... consider this: Barbara retired a few weeks ago as Director of Music for the New York City Department of Education.  
She told me today - we have been judges for years at the annual Music Memory city schools competition - that when she left the school system March 31 she left nearly a year of vacation on the table. 

She said it's a use-it or lose-it situation with vacation and retirement. So the decision she had to make: take a year vacation, and leave the music department she headed for 11 years without a director, or retire and allow the department she loves and cares for to get a new director. She decided on the latter, which meant she forfeited all that vacation. 

It's that passion and commitment to the 1.1 million public school students in New York City that doesn't get much attention when people talk about the country's biggest and most expensive school system. 
 
And so as she retires, I say,  Mazel Tov to Barbara .. and thank you for putting the interests of the children you've served for more than 4 decades in education above your own interests. Wow.  You will be missed.
name: Bill Ritter
title: Timeline Photos

content:
What an eventful meeting it turned out to be last week in the Oval Office of The White House tween President Donald J. Trump and the Russian Foreign Minister. 
In the course of 30 short minutes in a meeting one day after Mr. Trump fired FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation director James Comey: 

*The President shared classified information with the Russians, possibly endangering spies, angering a close ally (Israel) and  raising serious and important questions about whether allies will share sensitive intelligence with the US going forward.

*Mr. Trump told the Russians that Comey was a “nut job” and that firing the FBI Director has taken some pressure off the President and the Russia case.

*And - the U.S. media wasn't allowed in, but a Russian state photographer was. Some critics content this could be  a potential security breach.

One meeting last week.  For half an hour.

content:
#BreakingNews  
Former FBI Director Comey Agrees to Testify in Open Session at Senate Intel Committee 
 
News Release from the Committee: 

WASHINGTON –Senator Richard Burr (R-NC), Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, and Senator Mark Warner (D-VA), Vice Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, today announced that former Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey has committed to testify in open session before the Committee. The Committee will schedule the open hearing after Memorial Day. 
 
“The Committee looks forward to receiving testimony from the former Director on his role in the development of the Intelligence Community Assessment on Russian interference in the 2016 US elections, and I am hopeful that he will clarify for the American people recent events that have been broadly reported in the media,” said Senator Burr. 
 
“I hope that former Director Comey’s testimony will help answer some of the questions that have arisen since Director Comey was so suddenly dismissed by the President. I also expect that Director Comey will be able to shed light on issues critical to this Committee’s investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 election,” said Senator Warner. “Director Comey served his country with honor for many years, and he deserves an opportunity to tell his story. Moreover, the American people deserve an opportunity to hear it.”
 
###

content:
authorities have identified the suicide bomber responsible for last night's massacre at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, England.  He's 22 year old Salman Abedi, whose parents immigrated from Libya, and who lived just a few miles from the arena where he died. 
We will learn much more about him - our Josh Einiger is in Manchester for us tonight - but there has been some interesting discussions on social media about NOT naming the suspect -- with the assumption that somehow it helps inspire more terrorism. 
I think i understand that thinking - but, being in the news, I lean hard towards disclosure and sunlight and information and facts. Meaning... name the murderer, try to understand what makes a young man become radicalized into a Islamist extremist and who then commits the cowardly act of killing innocent people - including many children - in a terrorist act heralded by ISIS. 
What do you think? Name Abedi .. or not?
name: Bill Ritter
title: Police identify Manchester attacker as 22-year-old

content:
#BreakingNews British Prime Minister Theresa May just told England that she cannot ignore the wider possibility of individuals linked to the attack.
 She says the UK’s threat level has been raised from severe to critical. This entails deploying soldiers to the streets, among other changes.
 
Here’s what the threat levels mean:
•         Threat levels are designed to give a broad indication of the likelihood of a terrorist attack.
•         LOW means an attack is unlikely.
•         MODERATE means an attack is possible, but not likely
•         SUBSTANTIAL means an attack is a strong possibility
•         SEVERE means an attack is highly likely
•         CRITICAL means an attack is expected imminently

content:
The top choice of President Donald J. Trump to head FBI – Federal Bureau of Investigation has withdrawn his name from consideration. 
Former U.S. Sen. Joe Lieberman of Connecticut - once the Dem. VP candidate who supported John McCain in the race against Barack Obama in 2008 - has taken himself out of the running because he is senior counsel for the law firm that represents Mr. Trump in the federal investigation of Russia's attempt to impact the election, specifically by contacting Trump campaign staffers. 
Wrote Lieberman to the President: "I do believe it would be best to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest, given my role as a senior counsel in the law firm of which Marc (Trump's lawyer) is the senior partner.”
name: Bill Ritter
title: Timeline Photos

content:
Removing Confederate monuments - the speech by New Orleans by Mayor Mitch Landrieu is being heralded as a historic pivot in the south.  After the last of 4 Confederate monuments was removed last Friday, Landrieu - the first white Mayor of New Orleans since his father, Moon, 3 decades ago - talked profoundly about healing and understanding, and wondered why there are no monuments to slave ships, or to the lynchings that plagued the south and victimized blacks. 
The  Confederacy, he said, was on the wrong side of history. 
"We need to change,’’ he said. “And we need to change now. No more waiting. This is not just about statues, this is about our attitudes and behavior as well. If we take these statues down and don’t change to become a more open and inclusive society, this would have all been in vain.’’
name: Bill Ritter
title: Mayor Mitch Landrieu's full address on the removal of the Confederate monuments

content:
Donald J. Trump doesn't join in affirmation of G-7 "Paris Agreement."  Here's statement from G-7 

"The United States of America is in the process of reviewing its policies on climate change and on the Paris Agreement and thus is not in a position to join the consensus on these topics. Understanding this process, the Heads of State and of Government of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, and the United Kingdom and the Presidents of the European Council and of the European Commission reaffirm their strong commitment to swiftly implement the Paris Agreement, as previously stated at the Ise-Shima Summit."
name: Bill Ritter

content: A remarkable story. A woman from Long Island - fighting for decades to get her missing dad's remains back from Vietnam where he was shot down ..  now he's back and will be buried. Our Jim Dolan talks to the determined daughter on Monday -- a fitting Memorial Day story at 11 pm on ABC7NY
name: Bill Ritter
title: Pilot's remains back on US soil from Vietnam after 52 years
